section.title: Center of Mass Motion

subsection.title: Center of Mass Velocity, Acceleration, and Momentum
subsection.p:
Center of mass of an object provides an important way to follow the overall motion of the object. We have already seen the formula for the position of the center of mass. For a body that is a collection of discrete masses m_1 at \vec r_1, m_2 at \vec r_2, \cdots, m_N at \vec r_N, the center of mass will be at \vec R_\text{CM}, given by
\vec R_\text{CM} = \frac{1}{M}\left( m_1\vec r_1 + m_2\vec r_2 + \cdots + m_N\vec r_N \right),
where total mass M=m_1+m_2+\cdots+m_N and \vec r_i actually refer to the center of mass of the i^\text{th} part. Now, studying the rate at which the center of mass \vec R_\text{CM} changes will give us the velocity of center of mass, \vec V_{\text{CM}}. Taking a time derivate of both sides, it is immedeiately clear that
\vec V_{\text{CM}}\equiv \frac{d \vec R_\text{CM}}{dt} = \dfrac{m_1\vec v_1 + m_2\vec v_2 + \cdots + m_N\vec v_N }{M}.
Similarly, when we look at the rate which \vec V_{\text{CM}} changes, we get the acceleration of the center of mass, \vec A_{\text{CM}}. By taking one more derivative gives
\vec A_{\text{CM}}\equiv \frac{d \vec V_\text{CM}}{dt} = \dfrac{m_1\vec a_1 + m_2\vec a_2 + \cdots + m_N\vec a_N }{M}.

The total momentum of all particles will be
\vec p_\text{total} = m_1\vec v_1 + m_2\vec v_2 + \cdots + m_N\vec v_N.
Now, this is just M \vec V_{\text{CM}} as you can see from Eq. when you multiply it by M.
M \vec V_{\text{CM}} = m_1\vec v_1 + m_2\vec v_2 + \cdots + m_N\vec v_N
We call the product M \vec V_{\text{CM}} the center of mass momentum, \vec P_{\text{CM}}, which is actually equal to the total momentum of all particles in the body.
\vec P_{\text{CM}} = M \vec V_{\text{CM}} = \vec p_1 + \vec p_2 + \cdots + \vec p_N = \vec p_\text{total}.

subsection.title: Center of Mass Motion - Constant Mass Case
subsection.p: Let us consider a system with N parts of masses m_1 , m_2 , \cdots , m_N . Let \vec F_1 , \vec F_2 , \cdots , \vec F_N be forces acting on those parts. For the sake of simplicity, let us look at the constant mass system, i.e., where masss of each part is fixed in time.

Now, we write Newton's equation of motion for each part for constant mass.
\amp \vec F_1 = m_1 \vec a_1 \amp \vec F_2 = m_2 \vec a_2 \amp \cdots \amp \vec F_N = m_N \vec a_N
Summing them, we find that the left side can be written as sum over all the forces from objects outside the N parts making up the system, which we call the external forces \vec F_{\text{net}}^{\text{ext}}, and a sum over all the forces that one part applies on another part, wwhich we call the internal forces \vec F_{\text{net}}^{\text{int}}.
\text{Left Side } = \vec F_1 + \vec F_2 + \cdots + \vec F_N = \vec F_{\text{net}}^{\text{ext}} + \vec F_{\text{net}}^{\text{int}}
In this expression, internal forces, say by part 1 on 2 and by part 2 on 1 come in pairs, which by Newton's third law must sum to zero. Therefore, we will have
\vec F_{\text{net}}^{\text{int}} = 0.
That gives us the following simplified equation after summing the equations of all N parts.
F_{\text{net}}^{\text{ext}} = m_ 1\vec a_1 + m_2\vec a_2 + \cdots + m_N\vec a_N,
whose right side is just the total mass M times the center-of-mass acceleration \vec A_{\text{CM}} .
F_{\text{net}}^{\text{ext}} = M \vec A_{\text{CM}}.
It is interesting that the overall motion of a malti-part system can be captured essentially by the motion of a single (fictitious) particle of total mass placed at the center of mass. This is the equation we solve whenever we study the overall translation motion of finite-size objects since they are inherently mutiparticle systems.

Center of MassGeneral Motion We have seen before that the general case of mass varying as well as constant mass systems is given in terms of rate of change of momentum.
\vec F = \frac{d\vec p}{dt}.
Now, if you apply this to the N-particle system, you will get
F_{\text{net}}^{\text{ext}} = \frac{d\vec P_\text{CM}}{dt} = \frac{d\vec p_\text{total}}{dt}.
Similarly, the integrated form in terms of impulse and change in momentum will be
\vec J_{\text{net}}^{\text{ext}}= \int F_{\text{net}}^{\text{ext}} dt = \vec p_{\text{total},f} - \vec p_{\text{total},i},
i.e., the change in momentum over the interval i\rightarrow f is equal to the net impulse by only the external forces on various parts of the body.

section.example:
CM of an exploding shell
As an example consider the motion of pieces of an exploded shell in free-fall.
Although the pieces fly away in various directions, the CM falls as if no explosion had taken place since during the explosion all forces are internal to the system. The motion of CM is that of a single particle with total mass of the system. The fictitious particle at the CM falls freely with acceleration equal to g, the acceleration due to gravity, until one of the pieces hits the ground.
At the instant first piece hits the ground, there will be a new upward impulse on the collective body. That is, the CM's free fall motion will end.

example.title: The Motion of the Center of Mass of a Diver

statement.p: A diver jumps off a board with initial speed 12\text{ m/s} at an angle 60^\circ with the horizontal direction. She falls a total height of 8\text{ m} before entering water. Find the speed of her center of mass when she enters water?

solution.p:
Since the only force on her body after she takes off is her weight. The CM will obey the free fall equations. Therefore, we start with components of her initial velocity.
v_{ix} \amp = 12\,\cos\,60^{\circ} = 6\text{ m/s}, v_{iy} \amp = 12\,\sin\,60^{\circ} = 10.4\text{ m/s}.
The final v_x is same as the initial, and the final v_y is obtained from
v_{fy} = - \sqrt{ v_{iy}^2 - 2 g \Delta y},
where \Delta y = - 8\text{ m}, which is negative since the final location is below the initial point, and v_{fy} is negative since it is pointed down while positive y axis is pointed up.
v_{fy} = -\sqrt{ 10.4^2 + 2\times9.81\times 8} = -16.3\text{ m/s}.
From v_{fx} and v_{fy} we get the speed just before she enters water.
v_f = \sqrt{ v_{fx}^2 + v_{fy}^2 } = \sqrt{6^2 + 16.3^2} = 17.4\text{ m/s}.

statement.p: A 78.0\text{-kg} athlete jumps straight up so that his CM moves by a height of 1.2\text{ m} after he leaves the ground. Find the magnitude of impulse from the ground.

solution.p: The jump is due to push by the athlete on the ground which causes a normal force that exceeds his weight and gives upward momentum when he leaves the ground. This force from the ground during the jumping process is responsible for imparting initial upward momentum.

Let v_0 be the velocity pointed upwards at the instant athlete leaves the ground and m mass of the athlete. Then, the change in momentum from zero to mv_0 will equal the the impulse by ground. Let us work with y axis pointed up. Then, y-component of impulse will be
J_y = \Delta p_y = mv_0.,
The CM starts with velocity v_0 and has constant acceleration under the external force of gravity so that its velocity is zero at maximum height h. Using constant acceleration of the motion of CM along y axis we get
0 - v_0^2 = - 2 g h\ \ \longrightarrow\ \ v_0 = \sqrt{2gh}.
Hence, impulse by ground is
J = m\sqrt{2gh} = 78\sqrt{2\times 1.2\times 9.8} = 378.3\text{ N.s}.

p.p: Suppose you are trying to practice a vertical jump. You crouch down and push against the ground.

statement.p: The magnitude of the normal force from the ground on you varies with time as shown in of F versus t. The initial normal force is just your weight. As you push down, the normal force increases. You leave the ground at the point normal force is zero.
As a net result of normal force from the ground, and weight, your center of mass has acceleration upward. What will be your speed at the instant you are no longer in contact with the ground?

solution.p:
Let positive y axis be pointed up. We will implement the following law for the center of mass since CM momentum is equal to p_\text{tot}.
J_y^{\text{net}} = \Delta p_y^{CM}.
To get the net impulse, we need to vectorially add up impulses from all forces on the body. We have two forces on the body here - the weight and the normal force. From t=0 point in , we note that magnitude of weight is 500\text{ N}. Since weight has negative y component, its J_y will be negative.
J_y^{\text{weight}} = - 500\text{ N}\times 0.200\text{ s} = -100\text{ N.s}.
The impulse from the normal force is the area under the given plot.
J_y^{\text{normal}} \amp = \left( 500\times 0.2 - \dfrac{500\times 0.02}{2}\right) \amp \ \ \ \ + \dfrac{1000\times 0.08}{2} + 1000\times 0.02 + \dfrac{1000 \times 0.04}{2}, \amp = 175\text{ N.s},
which is obtained by slicing the area into triangles and rectangle. Therefore,
J_y^{\text{net}} = 175\text{ N.s} - 100\text{ N.s} = 75\text{ N.s}.
The mass of the person is obtained from the weight.
m = \dfrac{500\text{ N}}{9.81\text{ m/s}^2} = 51\text{ kg}.
Initially, the momentum was zero. Therefore, the velocity at the end is
v_{\text{cm}} = \dfrac{75\text{ N.s}}{51\text{ kg}} = 1.47\text{ m/s}.

exercise.title: Motion of Center of Mass of Two Blocks Attached by a Spring

sidebyside.p: Two blocks of mass m each is attached by a spring of spring constant k and unstretched length l_0. The blocks are placed on a horizontal frrictionless track.

statement.p: While holding one of the blocks, say B in the figure, the other block is pushed in so that spring compresses by D, and then everything is released from rest at t=0. Use x-axis so that at t=0, x_A=D and x_B=l_0.
Find the position of the center of mass, x_\text{cm}, at an arbitrary instant t.

hint.p: Since there is no external force, x_\text{cm} will remain fixed in time. You can show this by a detailed calculation.

solution.p: Since there is no external force, x_\text{cm} will remain fixed in time. Since the center of mass is at x=(D+l_0)/2 at t=0, it will remain there. This does not mean A and B do not move - they do, but their CM remains at the same point in space. We can also show this by a detailed calculation as follows.

sidebyside.p: shows situation at an arbitrary instant when the spring is stretched. The spring forces on the two blocks are shown.

solution.p:
The x-equations of motion for the two blocks will be
\amp m_A\frac{d^2x_A}{dt^2} = k (x_B - x_A - l_0) \amp m_B\frac{d^2x_B}{dt^2} = -k (x_B - x_A - l_0)
Here m_A=m_B=m and x_B \gt x_A. Since center of mass is give by
x_\text{cm} = \frac{1}{2}\left( x_A + x_B \right),
we can take two derivatives with respect to time to get
\frac{d^2x_\text{cm}}{dt^2}= \frac{1}{2}\left( \frac{d^2x_A}{dt^2} + \frac{d^2x_B}{dt^2} \right).
Using the equations of motions for x_A and x_B, we immediately get
\frac{d^2x_\text{cm}}{dt^2} = 0.
This has a simple solution.
x_\text{cm}(t) = a t + b,
where a and b will be fixed from the initial conditions.
x_A=D,\ \ x_B = l_0,\ \ v_A = 0 ,\ \ v_B=0.
Writing Eq. in terms of x_A and x_B and also writing their derivative we have
\amp \frac{1}{2}\left( x_A + x_B \right) = a t + b \amp \frac{1}{2}\left(v_A + v_B \right) = a
Evaluating these at t=0 we get
a = 0,\ \ b = \frac{D+l_0}{2}.
Therefore, we have the following answer for the center of mass at arbitrary instant t.
x_\text{cm} = \frac{D+l_0}{2}.
That is, CM remains fixed at x= (D+l_0)/2.

exercise.title: (Calculus) Motion of Center of Mass of Two Blocks Attached by a Spring with One Block Piushed Against a Wall

statement.p: In , the two blocks moved freely on the frictionless horizontal track.

sidebyside.p: Now, suppose you were pushing block A, you kept block B against a wall as shown in .

statement.p: After compressing the spring by amount D, you release both blocks at rest. What will be the motion of the center of mass if l_0 is the natural length of the spring?

hint.p: First solve the situation when block B is in contact with the wall. Then solve the situation after B loses contact with the wall. When in contact, set up equation of motion for the CM and another equation of motion for B. Also, use the relation between x_A and x_\text{cm}.

solution.p: The motion of the center of mass will be controlled by external forces on the two-block (and spring) system. When block B is in contact with the wall, the net external force on the two-block system comes from the normal force of the wall, which will vary with the varying length of the spring. When block B is no longer in contact with the wall, the normal force from the wall will be zero, which will make net external force zero on the two block system. Thus, after block B is no longer in contact with the wall, the center of mass will just move with a constant velocity.

p.alert: Block B in Contact with the Wall:

sidebyside.p:
shows situation at an arbitrary instant when block B is still in contact with the wall. The equation of motion of the center of mass will be
M \frac{d^2x_\text{cm}}{dt^2} = - N(t).

We need an expression for N(t) to solve this equation. We get that by looking at force on B as shown in . Balancing spring and wall forces on B gives
N(t) = k (l_0 - x_A).

solution.p:
We also note that when B is at the wall x_\text{cm} and x_A are related by
x_\text{cm} = \frac{m x_A + m l_0}{2m} = \frac{x_A + l_0}{2}.
Using the three equations above, we get the following equation of motion for x_\text{cm}.
\frac{d^2x_\text{cm}}{dt^2} = \frac{k}{m}\left(x_\text{cm} - l_0\right).
This has the following general solution.
x_\text{cm}(t) = l_0 + A\, e^{\sqrt{k/m}\, t} + B\, e^{-\sqrt{k/m}\, t}.
The velocity of CM will be
v_\text{cm}(t) = \sqrt{k/m}\,A\, e^{\sqrt{k/m}\, t}- \sqrt{k/m}\,B\, e^{-\sqrt{k/m}\, t}.
Using the initial conditions on A and B, we have the following intial conditions on CM.
\amp x_\text{cm}(t) = \frac{x_A (0)+ l_0}{2} = \frac{D+ l_0}{2}. \amp v_\text{cm}(t) = \frac{v_A (0)}{2} = 0.
Using these in Eqs. and , we find
A = B = \frac{D-l_0}{4}.
Therefore, the position of CM and its velocity are
\amp x_\text{cm}(t) = l_0 - \left(\frac{l_0-D}{2} \right)\,\cosh(\sqrt{k/m}\,t). \amp v_\text{cm}(t) = -\frac{(l_0-D)\sqrt{k/m}}{2}\,\sinh(\sqrt{k/m}\,t).

p.alert: Block B not in Contact with the Wall:

solution.p:
At the instant, block B loses contact with the wall, the CM will be at l_0/2. At that instant onward the velocity of the CM will remain unchanged since there are net external force on the two-block system is zero now. We can find the time when this happens from Eq. . Let this instant be at t=T.
\frac{l_0}{2} = l_0 - \left(\frac{l_0-D}{2} \right)\,\cosh(\sqrt{k/m}\,T)
Therefore,
T = \sqrt{\frac{m}{k}}\, \cosh^{-1}\left( \frac{l_0}{l_0 - D} \right).
From Eq. , the velocity of CM after this instant will be constat at
v_\text{cm}(t>T)\amp = - \frac{(l_0-D)\sqrt{k/m}}{2} \,\sinh(\sqrt{k/m}\,T) \amp = -\frac{(l_0-D)\sqrt{k/m}}{2}\,\sinh\left[ \cosh^{-1}\left( \frac{l_0}{l_0 - D} \right) \right].
This expression can be simplified by noting that
\sinh(\cosh^{-1}(x)) = \sqrt{x^2 - 1}.
To prove this try y=\cosh^{-1}(x) and solve for e^y = x + \sqrt{x^2-1} and e^{-y} = x - \sqrt{x^2-1}. Using this, we simplify CM velocity for t\gt T to be
v_\text{cm}(t>T) = -\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{ \frac{k}{m} (2l_0 D - D^2) }.
The velocity is x-component and pointed towards negative x-axis. That is why there is a negative sign in the front.
